#Text=Iriomote
#Text=Iriomote
#Text=( 西表 ) is the largest of the Yaeyama Islands of Okinawa , Japan .
#Text=Understand

#Text=While the second-largest of all Okinawa islands , Iriomote 's population is barely over 2,000 and visitors , at over 150,000 a year , outnumber residents by almost 100:1 . 90 % of the island is covered in dense jungles and swampy mangroves , most of which are either part of the Iriomote National Park or protected state land , and the island is unquestionably one of the few remaining great wildernesses of Japan .
#Text=Pretty much all of the island 's population lives along the coast .
#Text=Clockwise from the west , the major settlements are Shirahama ( 白浜 ) , Uehara ( 上原 ) , Funaura ( 船浦 ) and Ōhara ( 大原 ) .
#Text=The southern stretch between Ohara and Shirahama is effectively untouched coastline , with no roads and only a few isolated fishing villages near the western end .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Despite its size
#Text=Iriomote does not even have a landing strip , so all visitors must arrive by boat .
#Text=The nearest airport is in neighboring Ishigaki .
#Text=Two ports on the island have services from Ishigaki , operated by Anei Kankō and Yaeyama Kankō Ferry ( which share tickets offices and boat schedules ) , and by Ishigaki Dream Kankō Ferry .

#Text=Almost all visitors use the rapid services listed below , but dedicated penny-pinchers may opt for Yaeyama 's thrice-weekly slow cargo boats to Ohara ( 2 hours , ¥ 1070 ) and Uehara via Hatoma ( 3 hours , ¥ 1380 ) instead .
#Text=Round-trip tickets are generally available at about 10 % discount .
#Text=Apparently ( unverified ) there is also a 4-trip ticket for ¥ 5,000 which is an especially good deal when going to Uehara which costs about ¥ 4,000 round-trip to Ishigaki .
#Text=East coast
#Text=Ohara
#Text=, in the south-east coast , is the busiest port on the island and accessible in all but the very worst weather .
#Text=Anei , Yaeyama and Ishigaki Dream operate boats roughly hourly for a fixed ¥ 1540 and take about 35 minutes .
#Text=Northwest coast
#Text=Anei and Yaeyama boats both service to Uehara in the north of the island .
#Text=Both services cost ¥ 2000 and take about 40 minutes .
#Text=Some of them also stop in Hatoma , which makes the trip 15 minutes longer .
#Text=Ishigaki Dream also offers this route , but its two daily ferries stop in Hatoma and the whole trip takes around 70-80 minutes ( ¥ 1420 ) .
#Text=As of summer 2006 , nearby Funaura port is no longer used by regular ferry traffic .

#Text=Note that northwest coast services are subject to cancellation ( 欠航 kekkō ) if there is a strong north wind , which happens particularly frequently in the winter ( in autumn-winter 2016 , in average half the time ) .
#Text=In this case your ¥ 2000 will get you to Ohara by boat and then a free bus transfer to anywhere between Ohara and Shirahama .

#Text=In case of cancellation for the return to Ishigaki , allow one hour to go by bus from Uehara to Ohara where you will be able to take a ferry ( which follows Ohara schedule ) ; relevant time-tables for buses and ferries available at the bottom of this page .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The port Uehara is probably your preferred place to start exploring the island .
#Text=Most sights are relatively easy to reach from here .
#Text=Bike , Scooter , and Car rental is possible very close to the harbor .

#Text=Public transport on Iriomote is rather limited , but most lodges on the island offer free transfers to/from the nearest port , and both Anei and Yaeyama operate free shuttle services timed to meet ferry departures .
#Text=By bus

#Text=Iriomote Kōtsū runs 5 services per day in each direction from Shirahama to Funaura ( 30 min , ¥ 390 ) , 3 of which continue across the north coast to Ohara on the east ( from Funaura 50 min , ¥ 670 ) .
#Text=Tell the driver where you 're going when getting on and pay when you get off .
#Text=A three-day bus pass is also offered at ¥ 1000 per person .
#Text=On foot
#Text=The 20-km-long and demanding " Iriomote-jima Island Nature Trail " crosses the island .
#Text=The southern terminus is over 1 km from the Ohara port , and not labeled well , so a north-to-south passage , beginning with the Urauchi River cruise , is the recommended route .
#Text=The jungle is home to habu vipers , which though rare , are venomous .
#Text=After a Japanese hiker went missing in 2003 , signs now ask hikers attempting the cross-island hike to submit a proposal to the local police department .
#Text=By car
#Text=You can rent a car at several locations on the island .
#Text=One of them is at a gas station just outside of the Uehara port ( ) .
#Text=Important
#Text=: An international driver licence will not suffice .
#Text=An additional official translation into Japanese is required ( October 2016 ) .
#Text=The same conditions apply for scooter rentals , which are also available and a fun way to explore the island .
#Text=By bike
#Text=If all else fails or you like the idea , you can rent a bike .
#Text=Locks are usually not necessary and as a result you wo n't get one with you rental .
#Text=Bikes may be a cheap alternative ( as low as ¥ 500 ) but are usually very small ( people up to 165 cm can ride comfortably ) , which makes distances beyond 3 km a nuisance .
#Text=The Uehara gas station above also rents roadster bicycles with several gears and an integrated lock .
#Text=They are comfortable for people 180-cm tall and rental for several days is available .
#Text=Another place to rent out bikes , which is very close to the Uehara port , is Murata 's School of Nature ( ) .
#Text=Bikes are in good technical condition have a gear shift , but also have the size limitations as mentioned above .
#Text=See
#Text=Around a third of the island is designated as the Iriomote National Park ( 西表国立公園 Iriomote-kokuritsukōen ) , the only national park in all of Okinawa .
#Text=The park 's most famous denizen is the Iriomote wildcat ( イリオモテヤマネコ Iriomote yamaneko ) , an endangered creature found only on this island .
#Text=Alas , the critter is nocturnal and very rarely seen .

#Text=Other more readily viewable flora and fauna include the giant mangrove trees known as sakishimasuo-no-ki , a range of water birds , and lizards , including Japan 's largest lizard , a skink , reaching up to 2 feet in length .
#Text=Iriomote Wildlife Center
#Text=, on the east side of the island , provides information on Iriomote wildlife including the Yamaneko wild cat .
#Text=The center is open most days until 16:00 .
